member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an API is experimental and it may change in the future.
member.remarks: This attribute allows call sites to be flagged with a diagnostic that indicates that an experimental feature is used. Authors can use this attribute to ship preview features in their assemblies.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.
member.param: The ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.DiagnosticId
member.summary: Gets the ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.
member.remarks:
The diagnostic ID is shown in build output for warnings and errors.
This property represents the unique ID that can be used to suppress the warnings or errors, if needed.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.UrlFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL for corresponding documentation. The API accepts a format string instead of an actual URL, creating a generic URL that includes the diagnostic ID.
member.value: The format string that represents a URL to corresponding documentation.
member.remarks: An example format string is https://contoso.com/obsoletion-warnings/{0}.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.SetsRequiredMembersAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that this constructor sets all required members for the current type, and callers do not need to set any required members themselves.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

member.name: T:System.Index
member.summary: Represent a type can be used to index a collection either from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Construct an Index using a value and indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.param: The index value. it has to be zero or positive number.
Indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.remarks: If the Index constructed from the end, index value 1 means pointing at the last element and index value 0 means pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: P:System.Index.Start
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at first element.

member.name: P:System.Index.End
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromStart(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the start at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the start.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromEnd(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the end at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the end.

member.name: P:System.Index.Value
member.summary: Returns the index value.

member.name: P:System.Index.IsFromEnd
member.summary: Indicates whether the index is from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.GetOffset(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate the offset from the start using the giving collection length.
member.param: The length of the collection that the Index will be used with. length has to be a positive value
member.remarks: For performance reason, we don't validate the input length parameter and the returned offset value against negative values. we don't validate either the returned offset is greater than the input length. It is expected Index will be used with collections which always have non negative length/count. If the returned offset is negative and then used to index a collection will get out of range exception which will be same affect as the validation.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit
member.summary: Reserved to be used by the compiler for tracking metadata. This class should not be used by developers in source code.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:BizHawk.Common.DeltaSerializer
member.summary: Serializes deltas between data, mainly for ROM like structures which are actually writable, and therefore the differences need to be saved Uses a simple delta format in order to keep size down DELTA FORMAT DETAILS FOLLOWS The format comprises of an indeterminate amount of blocks. These blocks start with a 4 byte header. This header is read as a native endian 32-bit two's complement signed integer. If the header is positive, then the header indicates the amount of bytes which are identical between the original and current spans. Positive headers are blocks by themselves, so the next header will proceed immediately after a positive header. If the header is negative, then the header indicates the negation of the amount of bytes which differ between the original and current spans. A negative header will have the negated header amount of bytes proceed it, which will be the bitwise XOR between the original and differing bytes. A header of -0x80000000 is considered ill-formed. This format does not stipulate requirements for whether blocks of non-differing bytes necessarily will use a positive header. Thus, an implementation is free to use negative headers only, although without combination of positive headers, this will obviously not have great results wrt final size. More practically, an implementation may want to avoid using positive headers when the block is rather small (e.g. smaller than the header itself, and thus not shrinking the result). Subsequently, it may not mind putting some identical bytes within the negative header's block. XORing the same values result in 0, so doing this will not leave trace of the original data.

member.name: T:BizHawk.Common.PathExtensions.PathInternal
member.summary: Contains internal path helpers that are shared between many projects.
Contains internal path helpers that are shared between many projects.

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.PathExtensions.PathInternal.IsValidDriveChar(System.Char)
member.summary: Returns true if the given character is a valid drive letter

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.PathExtensions.PathInternal.EnsureExtendedPrefixIfNeeded(System.String)
member.summary: Adds the extended path prefix (\\?\) if not already a device path, IF the path is not relative, AND the path is more than 259 characters. (> MAX_PATH + null). This will also insert the extended prefix if the path ends with a period or a space. Trailing periods and spaces are normally eaten away from paths during normalization, but if we see such a path at this point it should be normalized and has retained the final characters. (Typically from one of the *Info classes)

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.PathExtensions.PathInternal.EnsureExtendedPrefix(System.String)
member.summary: Adds the extended path prefix (\\?\) if not relative or already a device path.

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.PathExtensions.PathInternal.IsDevice(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the path uses any of the DOS device path syntaxes. ("\\.\", "\\?\", or "\??\")

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.PathExtensions.PathInternal.IsExtended(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the path uses the canonical form of extended syntax ("\\?\" or "\??\"). If the path matches exactly (cannot use alternate directory separators) Windows will skip normalization and path length checks.

member.name: T:BizHawk.Common.HawkFile
member.summary:
This class can represent a variety of file-like objectsâ"regular" files on disk, archive members, SMB shares(?)âencapsulating them so any may be opened/read/closed like files on disk.
When opening an archive, it won't always be clear automatically which member should actually be used. Therefore, we define the concept of "binding": the attaches itself to an archive member, which is the file that it will actually be using.
We also define a simple extension to the Unix path format using '|': /path/to/file.rom is readable, but so is /path/to/archive.zip|member.rom. Strings formatted this way are annotated [HawkFilePath].
member.remarks:
This class is defensively designed around to allow swapping out implementations (for speed) without adding any dependencies to this project.
TODO split into "bind" and "open <the bound thing>"
TODO scan archive to flatten interior directories down to a path (maintain our own archive item list)

member.name: T:BizHawk.Common.HawkFilePathAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a string value is formatted as a path, with an extension to the format: paths followed by '|' and then a relative path represent a member of an archive file.
member.remarks:
The archive's path may be absolute or relative. If the path doesn't specify a member (it's a regular path), it obviously may also be absolute or relative.
The last '|' is the separator if multiple appear in the path, but the behaviour of such paths generally is undefined. Warnings may be printed on Debug builds.
Paths are still OS-dependent. C:\path\to\file and C:\path\to\archive|member are valid on Windows, /path/to/file and /path/to/archive|member are valid everywhere else.
This attribute is for humans.
TODO how are local (\\?\C:\file.txt) and remote (\\?\UNC\Server\Share\file.txt) UNCs treated by WinForms, and are we able to handle at least the valid ones? --yoshi

member.name: T:BizHawk.Common.TempFileManager
member.summary: Starts a thread which cleans any filenames in %temp% beginning with bizhawk.bizdelete. Files shouldn't be named that unless they're safe to delete, but notably, they may still be in use. That won't hurt this component. When they're no longer in use, this component will then be able to delete them.

member.exception: has an odd number of chars or contains a char not in [0-9A-Fa-f]

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Util.ToBoolBuffer(System.Byte[])
member.remarks: Any non-zero element is interpreted as .

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Util.ToIntBuffer(System.Byte[])
member.remarks: Each set of 4 elements in becomes 1 element in the returned buffer. The first of each set is interpreted as the LSB, with the 4th being the MSB. Elements are used as raw bits without regard for sign.

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Util.ToShortBuffer(System.Byte[])
member.remarks: Each pair of elements in becomes 1 element in the returned buffer. The first of each pair is interpreted as the LSB. Elements are used as raw bits without regard for sign.

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Util.ToUByteBuffer(System.Int32[])
member.remarks: Each element of becomes 4 elements in the returned buffer, with the LSB coming first. Elements are used as raw bits without regard for sign.

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Util.ToUByteBuffer(System.Int16[])
member.remarks: Each element of becomes 2 elements in the returned buffer, with the LSB coming first. Elements are used as raw bits without regard for sign.

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Zstd.CreateZstdCompressionStream(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a zstd compression stream. This stream uses a shared context as to avoid buffer allocation spam. It is absolutely important to call Dispose() / use using on returned stream. If this is not done, the shared context will remain in use, and the proceeding attempt to initialize it will throw. Also, of course, do not attempt to create multiple streams at once. Only 1 stream at a time is allowed per Zstd instance.
member.param: the stream to write compressed data
compression level, bounded by MinCompressionLevel and MaxCompressionLevel
member.returns: zstd compression stream
member.exception: compressionLevel is too small or too big

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Zstd.CreateZstdDecompressionStream(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Creates a zstd decompression stream. This stream uses a shared context as to avoid buffer allocation spam. It is absolutely important to call Dispose() / use using on returned stream. If this is not done, the shared context will remain in use, and the proceeding attempt to initialize it will throw. Also, of course, do not attempt to create multiple streams at once. Only 1 stream at a time is allowed per Zstd instance.
member.param: a stream with zstd compressed data to decompress
member.returns: zstd decompression stream

member.name: M:BizHawk.Common.Zstd.DecompressZstdStream(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Decompresses src stream and returns a memory stream with the decompressed contents. Context creation and disposing is handled internally in this function, unlike the non-static ones. This is useful in cases where you are not doing repeated decompressions, so keeping a Zstd instance around is not as useful.
member.param: stream with zstd compressed data to decompress
member.returns: MemoryStream with the decompressed contents of src
member.exception: src does not have a ZSTD header
